subject: Re: brief survey of reading research
msgSnippet: ... I just finished reading the article The Science of Word Recognition  (by Kevin Larson) ... thanks for posting the link to the web site. With regard to
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "ouphrontis" <allen_rouse@y...>
wrote:
>
> this may be of some interest to the group.
>
> via slashdot
>
> http://www.microsoft.com/typography/ctfonts/WordRecognition.aspx


I just finished reading the article "The Science of Word Recognition "
(by Kevin Larson) ... thanks for posting the link to the web site.

With regard to the Read alphabet, I found this statement very interesting:

"It is well known that words that have a consistent spelling to sound
correspondence such as mint, tint, and hint are recognized faster than
words that have an inconsistent spelling to sound correspondence such
as pint."

If this is true, given enough practice, we should be able to read text
written in QuikScript more rapidly than text written in the normal,
orthodox alphabet. Has anyone become proficient enough in reading
QuikScript text that they would say they can read it faster than they
can read regular text? Any estimates of how much time and practice it
might take reach this level?

Also, in some languages, words are spelled much more phonetically than
is English (a quick search on the internet says German and Japanese
are two such languages). Does anyone know whether or not people that
use these languages can actually read at faster rates? Could the
average German read a Harry Potter novel in less time than an average
American?

Jeff
